Civilization V is one of those rare games that still hits just as hard in 2025 as it did on release. I told myself I’d play a quick match before bed, and suddenly I’m Denmark launching coastal raids, puppeting cities, and realizing it’s 4AM. This game should honestly come with a warning label.

What makes Civ V timeless is how perfectly it blends strategy with personality.
Every civ feels unique. Every map tells a new story. Every decision matters.
Even when you think you’ve mastered it, the game hits you with something wild—your navy trapped behind borders, your capital starving, or that moment when the AI blindsides you with a carpet of doom.

The pacing is perfect.
The “just one more turn” addiction is REAL.

Even today, the community, mods, and replayability are unmatched. And unlike some newer entries in the series, Civ V never loses focus — the mechanics are clean, readable, and incredibly satisfying.

If you like strategy, history, or losing entire weekends without noticing… get this game.
You’ll thank me later (or blame me—depending on how many hours disappear).

11/10. Harald Bluetooth would approve.

If you’re here trying to choose which Civilization to play — because the reviews for VI and VII made you hesitate — you’ve landed at the right place.

The graphics still hold up, the gameplay is smooth and fluid, and there are no irrelevant civs pushing strange agendas.

It’s become my most-played game on Steam recently, and that alone deserves a review.
I’ve played it both alone and with friends, and my only real regret is that the Mac and PC versions aren’t compatible. No cross-platform play — just a reminder of simpler times.

It’s quick to get into and easy to understand without losing any depth.
Yes, it has its quirks — the AI behavior can be very random and often frustrating — but overall, it’s the least aggravating entry in the series.
You spend more time building your civilization the way you want than fighting against arbitrary constraints or random negative events.

That’s what makes this one special. You can take your Civ from the dawn of time to the future exactly how you envision it.
It’s not often mentioned, but that sandbox freedom is what made Civ V truly stand apart from the titles that came after.

When people say it’s “the last good Civ,” it’s because it’s the last one that really captures the essence of Civilization: guiding a people from early settlers to futuristic domination — without the game constantly derailing you for the sake of it.
Here, you actually get attached to your Civ. It’s yours, the one you have carefully engineered to fail or triumph.

Hey, it’s Civ 5, so why not write a review: This game for me is the peak of the whole civ-series. I was there with Civ 1 and I have played them all, more exactly Civ1-6, with all additional material I could get my fanboy-hands on, also “Test of Time”, "Revolution" (PS3) and of course "Alpha Centauri" and even "Beyond Earth". 
This series is the most important and impactful in my gaming life and I wouldn’t be the passionate gamer I am without those games. I am a history nerd and playing alternate timelines on a global dimension over and over again always caught me – over and over again. 
Civ 5 – for me – is nearly perfect in creating this special atmosphere of building an empire and competing on a global dimension throughout centuries, the music and sounds, the art style, the different mechanics – it all comes together so smoothly and naturally and the different leaders in the game are not just ridiculous caricatures of real historical figures, they have character. 

And there is, where my review shows yet another purpose, that is saying goodbye:

The first Civ, that didn’t hook me like this, was Civ 6. I didn’t have the feel of a global adventure anymore and the puzzle-aspect of citybuilding with the district system just wasn’t my cup of tea. Never say never, but with Civ 7 being out, that will be the first game of the series, I won’t buy. A few days ago I deleted Civ 7 from my wishlist – I watched at the shop page and facts are: the game is out since February this year, there are 15 buyable dlcs already and a confusing selection of bundles and packages/editions (we are in November now) – I don’t wanna comment on the state of the game, as I haven’t played it. 
I am just not part of the target group anymore, I guess, which is ok, since the franchise needs new players. I simply can’t approve of this kind of business “philosophy”, which in my opinion prioritizes tools and mechanics of greed instead of the actual gaming experience – coming from a nerd, that has bought, as I said, almost everything the series had to offer (Civ 5 was my first civ on steam, nevertheless I additionally bought Civ3, Civ4 complete again on steam). It’s not just about the money, they shall get, what they deserve, but for me it’s first and foremost about the game itself.

But I don’t want to conclude and say goodbye on a sour note. I want to thank Sid Meier and all of the people, who have worked on the series: You have enriched my gaming life more than any other game could ever have – for more than 30 years (HOLY f' MOLY). All the thousands of hours with the series were just wonderful and I have so many lovely memories that will remain, THANK YOU.

I liked playing Civ 2/3/4 back in the day, but having played Civ 5 for the first time in 2025, it seems to me like the game was either never particularly good, or that it has aged extremely poorly in comparison to more contemporary games and designs like Crusader Kings 3 or Against the Storm.

The technical issues alone are bad enough: at a resolution of 1440p, main menu and loading screens have huge black borders, and there's no UI scaling whatsoever, so all text and buttons both in menus and in-game are absolutely tiny. This alone already makes the game an absolute chore to play.

Regarding the art style, in a vacuum it's not bad, but for a strategy game I find it very hard to read. Whereas Civ 4 might look less pretty but at least one could always tell what was going on.

The game is also rather poor about presenting its information, e.g. there are a whole bunch of more or less hidden UI submenus.

Tutorialization is atrocious. The game is full of bizarre opaque mechanics (e.g. anything related to city states) and expects you to learn about them via pretty unhelpful advisors or the detailed in-game Civipedia which is essentially an in-game manual. Which, again, lacks any UI scaling, so the walls of text are absolutely tiny.

Turns take forever to resolve: despite the default settings (small map, continents, 5 civs total) and 2025 hardware vs. a 2010 game, by turn 250 passing the turn took 20+ seconds each time. Playing a larger game type? All 7 other opponents on the map are now hostile towards you! Smaller game? All 3! Barbarians? Yes YES! Only for you my friend! Endless endless barbarians just for you!
If you have friends to play this game with, it is a blast!  If you do not, I do not recommend this game to you. I do not recommend this game for those looking for a casual, (or even balanced) strategy game as you will have to disable so many "features" before you successfully win a game. If you're willing to put in the hours and time in order to "get good" to cover the skill gap to compete with the sometimes unforgiving AI, and have no interest in real time strategy games, or strictly war based games, this might be for you. 3/5
